content: Is it reasonable to think about relationally define reflexivity, symmetricity, transitivity in the Rel category, just like injectivity, surjectivity, bijectivity are defined via monic, epic, iso arrows. It is reasonable to constraint the problem as only equality, implication, and composition are legitimate operators involved? I would hope someone to not to show me the answer directly if they already know the answer to this question, but to help me a bit in my thinking process.

I am not sure about Rel\mathbf{Rel}Rel as a simple category, but Rel\mathbf{Rel}Rel is also a thin 222-category or a poset-enriched category. No matter if these terms don't mean anything to you, the important part is that for two morphisms R,S:X→YR,S: X \rightarrow YR,S:X→Y, you can talk about inclusions of one in the other. We say that R⊆SR\subseteq SR⊆S if and only if R(x,y)  ⟹  S(x,y)R(x,y) \implies S(x,y)R(x,y)⟹S(x,y) for all (x,y)∈X×Y(x,y) \in X\times Y(x,y)∈X×Y. Now you can try to figure out a way to use this additional structure to talk about relfexivity, symmetry and transitivity.
What is thin 2-category and poset-enriched category? What's the difference between these and what you would call "simple category"?

It is not really important. In short it tells you that the inclusion is a partial order on Hom(X,Y)\mathrm{Hom}(X,Y)Hom(X,Y) (i.e. it is reflexive, transitive and antisymmetric) and it behaves well with composition.

I meant it is not important for now. I first want to see if Peiyuan can find how to characterize reflexivity, symmetry and transitivity using only composition, identities and inclusion. After that, we could dig into the details.

FWIW: I presume by "simple category" you mean "ordinary category", i.e. not poset-enriched. But "simple" is a bit of a dangerous word to use in the "ordinary" way in mathematics, as mathematicians like to give it complicated meanings. For instance, in the context of [[FOLDS]] a "simple category" means a skeletal one-way category with finite fan-out. (-:O

When I begin my investigation, I wonder what kind of property shall I aim for? It seems that monic arrows iff injective but surjective implies but isn't identical to epic. So it looks like a weaker condition than the original one is okay, as long as it holds in most cases? (Please again don't give out the answer, just help me to think about it, or explain why this is acceptable, e.g. is it because you're working on a generalization?)

Let us start with something else. Do you know about the opposite of a relation? If you have a relation R⊆X×YR\subseteq X\times YR⊆X×Y, the oppoiste of RRR is a relation Rop⊆Y×XR^{\mathrm{op}} \subseteq Y \times XRop⊆Y×X defined by (y,x)∈Rop⇔(x,y)∈R(y,x) \in R^{\mathrm{op}} \Leftrightarrow (x,y) \in R(y,x)∈Rop⇔(x,y)∈R.

In Rel\mathbf{Rel}Rel, RRR is a morphism X→YX \rightarrow YX→Y and Rop:Y→XR^{\mathrm{op}}: Y \rightarrow XRop:Y→X, so we have composites R;Rop:X→XR;R^{\mathrm{op}}: X \rightarrow XR;Rop:X→X and Rop;R:Y→YR^{\mathrm{op}}; R: Y \rightarrow YRop;R:Y→Y (I write composition of relations in diagrammatic order, i.e. R;Rop=Rop∘RR;R^{\mathrm{op}} = R^{\mathrm{op}} \circ RR;Rop=Rop∘R).

What does it mean for the first composite to be equal to idX\mathrm{id}_XidX​? What if the second is equal to idY\mathrm{id}_YidY​? What if both are true?
Conjecture: R⊂R∘R−1R\subset R\circ R^{-1}R⊂R∘R−1 is a generalization of reflexivity. I need to run now but I'll verify this later.
